discussion.content: I found this on the BMC.com : Transport. The fourth layer of the OSI model ensures complete and reliable delivery of data packets. The transport layer provides mechanisms such as error control, flow control, and congestion control to keep track of the data packets, check for errors and duplication, and resend the information that fails delivery.

Selected Answer: D
The transport layer
The answer is D

Selected Answer: D
this feels too easy lol

the answer is D

transport

questions.question_text: Which of the following OSI model layers will ensure messages are transmitted to their destinations and no data is duplicated?

I didn't have this sim the last time but before I passed, I saw this. Be sure that you put 10.1.90.53 as correct answer when asked about the ip address
All answers are correct, but only confusion I have is that I suppose its router A cause the ping failed but its router B showing as device failed so that's a little confusing.

comments.content: And for the last question, the workstation is still Router A?

1. The reason is that wan 2 has only 0.01% loss which and latency and jitter is lower which is important in VOIP traffic. Higher latency and jitter will result to delay in calls.

2. Router A because ping failed. And for the last question I think the correct answer should be 10.1.90.53 because the question is asking for a workstation

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-

A network technician was recently onboarded to a company. A manager has tasked the technician with documenting the network and has provided the technician with partial information from previous documentation.


INSTRUCTIONS
-

Click on each switch to perform a network discovery by entering commands into the terminal. Type help in each terminal to view a list of available commands.

Fill in the missing information using the drop-down meus provided.

If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.

//IMG//

discussion.content: I had this on my test. I passed 3 days ago. It was simple. All you need to do is go to the core 1 switch and run the help and then use the cmd to look at the arp table and cross reference data. It's super simple on the test seeing it here did help.
I have no idea how to answer this question

Make sure you check the status of the connections linking core to access. The access switches are going to have the most relevant data of their MAC tables if they are not connected to the core switch. Might of been a trick but the tech who "prefills" some of the info I think just used the info he got from the core switch.

This question is definitely relevant for anybody taking the Network+ in the near future. Literally took my exam this morning and saw this PBQ. As others have mentioned, just type help and you will be provided with the following commands:
show interfaces
show ip arp
show mac address-table
show vlan

I used the info from the core switch because the other devices' info didn't make sense, but that's just me. I hope this helps everyone who takes the exam. Good luck! Also, I passed with a 784.

P.S. For anyone wondering if this site is trustworthy... YES IT IS! I'd say about 90% of my questions were literally word-for-word the same as this site. It definitely helped a lot.

I had this PBQ too. Passed the exam. Most of the questions are all on here. 

To complete this PBQ on the exam you have to go into the Core Switch terminal. Type '?' and it will list what commands you can use. The 'show interfaces' command will list all the mac addresses and IP addresses. 

It's confusing at first, but then it starts to make sense. You just have to read carefully and match up the right mac addresses to the corresponding VLANs and IP addresses. 

TBH, nothing worth memorizing here, because the VLANs for each device will depend on what you pick, and the order you put them in. One of the easier PBQ's IMO.

comments.content: Were most questions that you found on the exam towards the very end of this dump? Or just scattered everywhere?
Hi where you able to find out if most questions where towards the end of this or more in the beginning?

discussion.content: I had this on my exam July 28 2024... this question came out. But the answer options here were not the same as the actual exam.. any updates??? The options where more like mitagtions

got this on my exam 3 days ago. You can click on the switches and use the 'help' command to show commands available. The top switch will have show arp table which has most of the information you need to complete the missing fields. All i remember is:
device 1 : vlan 10 
device 2 : vlan 10 
device 3 : vlan 10 
device 4 : vlan 20 
Whatever info you can't populate from the top switch with Show arp table you will find in the switches connected directly to devices under 'show mac address-table'
this should help you fill in all the blanks, don't panic, this exercise is actually quite easy
what command prompts give you the VLAN and Interface information?

comments.content: just click on the switches and type 'help' . they will list the 4 commands available, which you can just type in to get the results you need

discussion.content: This one a little confusing for me. I'm assuming we need to open up the "command prompt on each switch and enter some commands. I'm not that great with "cmd" are we using cisco commands like "show ip interface brief" or will arp -a work?

It was on my exam and 100% same. You can type 'help' to see specific commands to figure out which ones you should use. It's little bit tricky (loooots of info/numbers...) so you will need some time for this question to answer. Also, there was another simulation question which is very similar with this one too. I recommend you practice simple commands on switches to find PCs' network information. If you can solve this question easy/fast, another question that I mentioned would be a piece of cake.
I took my exam on April 25, 2024 and this question came out. I passed with a 729, thank u exam topic
You people aren't getting it because you have to go into this freaking terminal
What are they asking or are we missing some templates

So on mine i just used the core switch to fill in everything. ? in prompt to see commands and use all. When i looked at the other 2 switches the info didnt seem to make sense. some fields will have info in them already so i was able to find everything in the core by cross referencing the ones that were already filled in. idk if right but only thing that made sense.

so i had this question in the exam and i am still stuck on one thing. so in the exam i was able to interact with the server and switches to review the config. by using the '?' command, it brought up the arp table, the interface stats, the mac table and something else. by using this command i was able to narrow down which computer had which IP address and so forth. HOWEVER the data stored on each device had mismatching values, and i was not able to use a ping command. I ended up having to take an estimated guess on some, but im still trying to work out why and how the switches and servers had different ARP and MAC tables.
anyone can jump on this? I just don't get it

questions.question_text: A Wi-Fi network was recently deployed in a new, multilevel building. Several issues are now being reported related to latency and drops in coverage. Which of the following is the first step to troubleshoot the issues?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Itâ€™s B. O yea

Selected Answer: C
Site survey should have been conducted upon installation of the APs including a heat map. I'm going with C.

Selected Answer: B
I'm in agreeance that this is B
Question #: 247 is exactly the same but with some different answers. I'm gonna go with C here because it matches up. and the previous question was a 50/50 split between a and c with 60+ votes

Selected Answer: B
It says which should you do first, so I would make sure the AP is in a good spot. If it is, then I would do C next.
(Easiest/Simplest first)

Selected Answer: B
Question specifies "drops in coverage", must be AP placement

Selected Answer: C
channels could overlap on the different floors of the building. question 247 has this exact question except it includes site survey.
B should be correct

Selected Answer: B
It's B. There's no way you'd move a server to a core switch, not only that, but the servers are also on the access switch, what good would that do? 
You need LACP to increase bandwidth during busy times.

Selected Answer: B
Moving a server to the Core switch is very bad and pointless practise. 
LACP will provide better speed for the server link.

Selected Answer: D
I don't normally like ChatGPT, but I actually think its response is helpful here to clarify:

While implementing LACP could help distribute traffic more evenly across multiple links and provide redundancy, it may not fully address the performance issues experienced during busy times. Therefore, moving the server connection to the core switch (option D) is likely to be a more comprehensive solution in this scenario.

Selected Answer: B
be is correct

Selected Answer: D
D. Move the server connection from the access switch to the core switch.
As a Sr DBA, I would look at the database server and see if it needs CPU, Ram, Stats updated or indexes defragmented.... But that is outside of the scope of this test.

questions.question_text: Users report that a database server responds slowly or drops connections to other servers at random during busy times. A technician notices the database and servers are connected to an access switch in the office. Which of the following should the technician do to improve the performance of the database server?

choices.C: Move the cable connection for users to the same switch as the database server.
choices.B: Implement LACP on the connection to the database server.
choices.A: Use different ports on the access switch.
choices.D: Move the server connection from the access switch to the core switch.
